Caprini JA. Thrombosis risk assessment as a guide to quality patient care. Dis Mon. 2005 Feb-Mar;51(2-3):70-8. doi: 10.1016/j.disamonth.2005.02.003. PMID: 15900257.
Caprini JA, Arcelus JI, Hasty JH, Tamhane AC, Fabrega F. Clinical assessment of venous thromboembolic risk in surgical patients. Semin Thromb Hemost. 1991;17 Suppl 3:304-12. PMID: 1754886.
Obi AT, Pannucci CJ, Nackashi A, Abdullah N, Alvarez R, Bahl V, Wakefield TW, Henke PK. Validation of the Caprini Venous Thromboembolism Risk Assessment Model in Critically Ill Surgical Patients. JAMA Surg. 2015 Oct;150(10):941-8. doi: 10.1001/jamasurg.2015.1841. PMID: 26288124.

details.purpose: To record values for individual Caprini score parameters and the total score.
details.use: Use to record values for individual Caprini score parameters and the total score as part of a pre-operative assessment for venous thromboembolism.

items.items: Assessment tool used to stratify risk for venous thromboembolism (VTE).
Venous thromboembolism (VTE), a disease which includes deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Used to drive UI presentation of pregnancy or hormone related risks only.
Major surgery (>45 minutes), laparoscopic surgery (>45 minutes) or arthroscopic surgery
Serious lung disease, including pneumonia (<1 month)
For example: multiple broken bones due to a fall; or car accident.
Bed rest or restricted mobility during past month
For example: Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis.
Current oral contraceptives or hormone replacement
The total sum of each component parameter for the Caprini score.
History of unexplained stillborn infant, recurrent spontaneous abortion (â¥3 factors present), premature birth with toxaemia or growth restricted infant.
Additional information required to extend the model with local content or to align with other reference models or formalisms.
For example: local information requirements; or additional metadata to align with FHIR.
